me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.kinematics

Class RelativeSwerveDriveKinematics

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.kinematics.RelativeSwerveDriveKinematics
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Kinematics<RelativeSwerveState>

    public class RelativeSwerveDriveKinematics
extends java.lang.Object
implements Kinematics<RelativeSwerveState>
    The simplest form of swerve drive kinematics. This class operates very simply - each of the four swerve modules has its own RelativeSwerveModuleKinematics instance responsible for controlling the module's angle and power. The only thing this class does differently is incorporating turn values.

    Unlike other popular swerve drive implementations, turning is not handled by rotating the wheels - rather, turning is handled by adjusting the power of each of the wheels. This, functionally, doesn't have very much of a difference - it does make it a bit more challenging to do complex math related to the robot's center of rotation and all that, but it works quite simply and quite well.

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Constructor Detail

      • RelativeSwerveDriveKinematics

        public RelativeSwerveDriveKinematics(RelativeSwerveModuleKinematics moduleKinematics,
                                     java.util.function.Supplier<Angle> frontRightModuleAngle,
                                     java.util.function.Supplier<Angle> frontLeftModuleAngle,
                                     java.util.function.Supplier<Angle> backRightModuleAngle,
                                     java.util.function.Supplier<Angle> backLeftModuleAngle,
                                     double turnMultiplier)
        Create a new instance of the relative swerve drive kinematics class by using the same module kinematics for each of the swerve modules. This, in almost all cases, should function exactly the same as if every module had their own kinematics. The only difference is that this constructor requires three fewer parameters.
        Parameters:
        moduleKinematics - the swerve module kinematics for all four of the chassis' modules.
        frontRightModuleAngle - the front right module's angle.
        frontLeftModuleAngle - the front left module's angle.
        backRightModuleAngle - the back right module's angle.
        backLeftModuleAngle - the back left module angle.
        turnMultiplier - the chassis' turn multiplier. Having a higher turn multiplier means the robot will turn faster. Having a lower turn multiplier will mean the robot will turn slower. Typically, this value should be somewhere between 0.5 and 1 - but you'll have to do some testing and figure out what works best for you. Also, having a negative turn multiplier will mean the chassis will turn in the opposite direction.

      • RelativeSwerveDriveKinematics

                                     java.util.function.Supplier<Angle> backLeftModuleAngle,
                                     double turnMultiplier)
        Create a new instance of the relative swerve drive kinematics class.
        Parameters:
        frontRightKinematics - the front right module's kinematics.
        frontLeftKinematics - the front left module's kinematics.
        backRightKinematics - the back right module's kinematics.
        backLeftKinematics - the back left module's kinematics.
        frontRightModuleAngle - the front right module's angle.
        frontLeftModuleAngle - the front left module's angle.
        backRightModuleAngle - the back right module's angle.
        backLeftModuleAngle - the back left module angle.
        turnMultiplier - the chassis' turn multiplier. Having a higher turn multiplier means the robot will turn faster. Having a lower turn multiplier will mean the robot will turn slower. Typically, this value should be somewhere between 0.5 and 1 - but you'll have to do some testing and figure out what works best for you. Also, having a negative turn multiplier will mean the chassis will turn in the opposite direction.

      • calculateOptimized

        public RelativeSwerveState calculateOptimized(Translation translation)
        Calculate an optimized swerve state based on a translation.

        My left hand feels like it's about to fall off from typing this much, so I'm just gonna ask you to go read the documentation in the swerve module state class about optimization to figure it out. Good luck!

        Parameters:
        translation - the translation the robot should follow.
        Returns:
        an optimized swerve state according to that translation.
